articles.headline: The F.A.O. Schwarz Piano Is Back — but With a Different Tune
articles.snippet: A private equity-backed company is reintroducing the storied toy seller with a new business model.
articles.abstract: A private equity-backed company is reintroducing the storied toy seller with a new business model.
articles.lead_paragraph: The dance-on piano, immortalized by Tom Hanks in the movie “Big,” is back. So are the toy soldiers in towering black hats and the theme song “Welcome to Our World of Toys.” There is even a flagship store in New York.

articles.headline: Why the Announcement of a Looming White Minority Makes Demographers Nervous
articles.snippet: The idea of white demographic decline has become an object of fascination on the right and the left. But demographers have grown uneasy with the projection.
articles.abstract: The idea of white demographic decline has become an object of fascination on the right and the left. But demographers have grown uneasy with the projection.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The graphic was splashy by the Census Bureau’s standards and it showed an unmistakable moment in America’s future: the year 2044, when white Americans were projected to fall below half the population and lose their majority status.

articles.headline: Saudis Want a U.S. Nuclear Deal. Can They Be Trusted Not to Build a Bomb?
articles.snippet: The question of whether Saudi Arabia should be allowed to make its own nuclear fuel has intensified after the Saudi assassination of Jamal Khashoggi and the cover-up that followed.
articles.abstract: The question of whether Saudi Arabia should be allowed to make its own nuclear fuel has intensified after the Saudi assassination of Jamal Khashoggi and the cover-up that followed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Before Saudi Arabia’s crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, was implicated by the C.I.A. in the killing of Jamal Khashoggi, American intelligence agencies were trying to solve a separate mystery: Was the prince laying the groundwork for building an atomic bomb?
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Says Europe Must ‘Get a Handle’ on Migration to Thwart Populism
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton, in an interview with The Guardian, argued that migration policies contributed to the rise in right-wing populism in Europe.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton, in an interview with The Guardian, argued that migration policies contributed to the rise in right-wing populism in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: Europe’s leaders need to send a much stronger message that they will no longer offer “refuge and support” to migrants if they want to curb the right-wing populism spreading across the Continent, Hillary Clinton warned in an interview published Thursday.
articles.byline: By Matt Stevens, Megan Specia and Patrick Kingsley

articles.headline: In China, a School Trains Boys to Be ‘Real Men’
articles.snippet: Employing American football and chest-thumping chants, Tang Haiyan offers an answer to a country that worries that its sons are too coddled and feminine. “We will never cultivate sissies,” he says.
articles.abstract: Employing American football and chest-thumping chants, Tang Haiyan offers an answer to a country that worries that its sons are too coddled and feminine. “We will never cultivate sissies,” he says.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tang Haiyan runs his school with a clear mission in mind: He will train boys to be men.

articles.headline: Ghosn Arrest Exposes Stress in Japanese-French Auto Marriage
articles.snippet: The arrest of Carlos Ghosn hit Nissan, Renault and Mitsubishi as they confront a global slowdown, a trade war and a major shift in technology.
articles.abstract: The arrest of Carlos Ghosn hit Nissan, Renault and Mitsubishi as they confront a global slowdown, a trade war and a major shift in technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is probably never a good time for an auto empire to have its leader thrown in jail. But for Nissan and Renault, the arrest of Carlos Ghosn comes at an especially inopportune moment.

articles.headline: Meet Zora, the Robot Caregiver
articles.snippet: This robot is at the center of an experiment in France to change care for elderly patients.
articles.abstract: This robot is at the center of an experiment in France to change care for elderly patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: This robot is at the center of an experiment in France to change care for elderly patients.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano, Elian Peltier and Dmitry Kostyukov

articles.headline: How Guy Raz Built ‘How I Built This’
articles.snippet: The astonishment-prone host (Wow!) has turned a pure zeal for business (It’s amazing!) into a juggernaut podcast. (What is that like?!)
articles.abstract: The astonishment-prone host (Wow!) has turned a pure zeal for business (It’s amazing!) into a juggernaut podcast. (What is that like?!)
articles.lead_paragraph: Guy Raz is wrapping up an episode of How I Built This, his podcast about the origin stories of late capitalism, when his guest, the Israeli investor Haim Saban, gets to the good part. The throw-your-arms-aloft, finish-line moment of his personal business journey. In the story Mr. Saban is telling, he is about to make a lot of money, and then quadruple it into even more money.
